title: Next Massive Volcanic Eruption ‘May Be Due This Century’, Says Report: ‘Humanity Has No Plan’ - ABP Live
summary:
Next Massive Volcanic Eruption ‘May Be Due This Century’, Says Report: ‘Humanity Has No Plan’

Published on: October 2023

Source: CNN

The Earth’s geological activity suggests a significant volcanic eruption could occur within this century, with scientists warning of the potentially devastating climate consequences similar to the 1815 Mount Tambora eruption.

Key Points:

  • Scientists indicate a 1-in-6 chance of a massive eruption occurring this century.
  • The eruption could lead to 'climate chaos' according to climate expert Markus Stoffel.
  • The Mount Tambora eruption resulted in global temperature drops, crop failures, and significant loss of life.
  • Recent seismic activity at Mount Tambora raises concerns about future eruptions.
  • Experts suggest preparing for volcanic eruptions through scenario assessments and emergency plans.
“Humanity does not have any plan” for such an eventuality, Markus Stoffel.

In conclusion, while the possibility of a massive volcanic eruption looms, proactive measures and planning are necessary to mitigate potential consequences.
newTitle: Next Massive Volcanic Eruption May Occur This Century, Experts Warn

title: 5 Big Space Missions To Look Forward To In 2025 - Times Now
summary:
5 Big Space Missions To Look Forward To In 2025

Publication Date: Dec 26, 2024 Source: Times Now Digital

2025 promises to be a year of exciting space exploration. Here are five missions to watch out for.

  • Astronauts Finally Returning Home: Two NASA astronauts will return home aboard a SpaceX capsule.
  • NASA's TRACERS Mission: Launches in April to study solar wind interactions.
  • Artemis II Lunar Flyby: A crewed mission to orbit the Moon is scheduled for late 2025.
  • Tianwen-2 and BepiColombo Missions: Tianwen-2 will study an asteroid, while BepiColombo will explore Mercury.
  • India’s Gaganyaan Human Spaceflight: Expected to send astronauts into orbit, marking a significant milestone for India.
India’s Gaganyaan mission will make India the fourth nation to achieve human spaceflight, joining the US, Soviet Union, and China.

The upcoming space missions in 2025 represent significant advancements in space exploration and technology, with implications for international cooperation and scientific innovation.
newTitle: 5 Big Space Missions To Look Forward To In 2025

Source: Gadgets 360

The crew aboard the International Space Station (ISS) celebrated Christmas by sharing holiday cheer and emphasizing togetherness, even from an orbiting outpost 260 miles above Earth.

  • Astronauts created a festive atmosphere with floating decorations and a snowman made from storage bags.
  • They acknowledged the efforts of mission control teams on Earth who support their work.
  • The crew enjoyed a special meal and decorations that reminded them of their families.
  • Barry Wilmore highlighted the religious significance of Christmas during their celebrations.
“Merry Christmas” from our extraordinary vantage point!” - ISS Crew

The celebration highlighted the unity and collaboration that define both their mission and the holiday spirit.

title: NASA Parker Solar Probe Makes Closest-Ever Approach to the Sun - Observer Voice
Lumpy universe does not require dark energy - News9 LIVE
summary:
Lumpy universe does not require dark energy

Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

Scientists have proposed a solution to a major cosmological issue: the universe's expansion may not be accelerating as previously thought, leading to a reevaluation of dark energy concepts.

  • The 'timescape' model suggests that the universe's uneven expansion creates the illusion of acceleration.
  • Local matter density is thought to be lower, leading to perceptions of rapid expansion from our vantage point.
  • Future data may clarify the expanding universe mystery within five years.
“Dark energy is a misidentification of variations in the kinetic energy of expansion, which is not uniform in a universe as lumpy as the one we actually live in.” - David Wiltshire

This research prompts reconsideration of fundamental cosmological concepts, highlighting gravitational influences on cosmic time perception.
newTitle: Lumpy Universe Model Challenges Dark Energy Theory

title: The earth’s largest hidden underwater waterfall: A 11,500-ft giant under the Arctic - The Times of India
summary:
The Earth’s Largest Hidden Underwater Waterfall: A 11,500-ft Giant Under the Arctic

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Times of India

Deep beneath the Arctic waters between Greenland and Iceland lies the world’s largest waterfall—hidden from sight but crucial to Earth's climate. The Denmark Strait cataract, an underwater giant, influences global ocean circulation and shapes ecosystems despite its invisible and silent presence.

  • The Denmark Strait cataract has a vertical drop of 11,500 feet, over three times the height of Angel Falls.
  • This underwater phenomenon spans 300 miles (480 kilometers) and operates unseen beneath the Arctic waters.
  • It is formed from glacial forces and dates back to the last ice age.
  • This massive underwater waterfall plays a critical role in regulating ocean circulation and the planet's climate.
  • It helps drive thermohaline circulation, distributing heat, nutrients, and energy across oceans.
  • The waterfall is essential for maintaining Earth's ecosystems and influences marine life directly.
Marine geosystems expert Mike Clare mentioned that the water of the Denmark Strait cataract is virtually unnoticed even by those underwater, moving silently without dramatic visual effects.

The Denmark Strait cataract represents a hidden marvel of nature that plays a crucial role in climate regulation and ocean health, highlighting the importance of our oceans in maintaining planetary equilibrium.
newTitle: The Earth’s Largest Hidden Underwater Waterfall: A 11,500-ft Giant Under the Arctic

title: Bright, elliptically polarized incandescent light - Tech Explorist
summary:
Bright, elliptically polarized incandescent light

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Tech Explorist

This article discusses groundbreaking research from the University of Michigan that enables the production of bright, twisted light using technology reminiscent of traditional incandescent bulbs.

  • Traditional methods for producing twisted light are challenging; new techniques have been developed based on blackbody radiation.
  • Photons emitted by heated objects can become polarized depending on the object's shape and size.
  • Chiral or twisted light is characterized by its unique clockwise and counterclockwise rotations.
  • The findings could significantly impact technologies like autonomous vehicles, aiding in object identification.
  • This method could result in light that is 100 times brighter than existing techniques, though it presents challenges in wavelength refinement.
  • Future research aims to expand the application of twisted light into the infrared spectrum.
“The advancements in physics of blackbody radiation by chiral nanostructures are central to this study. Such emitters are everywhere around us.” - Nicholas Kotov

In conclusion, these findings not only advance the field of optics but also open avenues for practical applications in technology that relies on visual identification and contrast enhancement.
newTitle: Researchers Develop Bright Twisted Light Using Edison Bulb Technology

title: Astronomers unveil stunning new view of NGC 2264, the “Christmas Tree Cluster” - News9 LIVE
summary:
Astronomers Unveil Stunning New View of NGC 2264, the 'Christmas Tree Cluster'

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: Science News

A stunning new picture of the galaxy NGC 2264, called the ‘Christmas Tree Cluster,’ has been published just in time for the holiday season. This beautiful nebula is approximately 2,500 light years from Earth and is home to stars that are between one and five million years old.

  • The X-ray data was obtained from the Chandra X-ray Observatory.
  • Optical data was captured by Michael Clow in Arizona.
  • The image showcases vibrant colors representing star density and gas motion.
  • Astronomers gain insights into star formation and the influence of young stars on their environment.
  • The visual representation resembles a decorated Christmas tree, highlighting both art and science.
“The image is a true art and science combination with a festive message as to how beautiful and intricate the universe is.”

This new image not only captures the beauty of the cosmos but also provides valuable insights into astrophysical processes, celebrating the wonder of the universe as we enter the holiday season.
newTitle: Astronomers Unveil Stunning New View of NGC 2264, the 'Christmas Tree Cluster'

“Webb’s infrared vision can peer through dust to observe cosmic phenomena like never before.”

The James Webb Telescope continues to redefine our perspective of the cosmos, revealing exquisite details and contributing significantly to astronomical discoveries.

title: Equal to a trillion hydrogen bombs: Is the Sun readying for a violent super explosion? - MSN
Yearly round-up: The biggest science stories of 2024 - Deccan Herald
summary:
Yearly round-up: The biggest science stories of 2024

Published on 26 December 2024 by Deccan Herald

As humanity completed another revolution around the Sun, science threw up some fascinating findings this year. Here’s a look at some of the biggest stories in science for 2024.

  • The hottest year on record: 2024 has been declared the hottest year since records began in 1850, with severe heatwaves across the globe.
  • HIV prevention drug shows immense promise: The FDA-approved drug lenacapavir demonstrated 96%-100% success rates in two trials.
  • In search of extraterrestrial life: NASA's Clipper mission targets Jupiter's moon Europa for signs of life.
  • A perfect storm: The northern lights were visible far beyond their typical range due to solar activity.
  • Mapping a fruit fly's brain: Researchers mapped a fruit fly's brain containing over 140,000 neurons.
  • Detecting Alzheimer's: A new blood test for Alzheimer's showed 88%-92% accuracy, simplifying detection.
  • Human-Neanderthal breeding timeline: Interbreeding between humans and Neanderthals determined to have occurred around 50,500 to 43,500 years ago.
  • Gene editing with a dash of AI: CRISPR technology is enhanced with AI, resulting in a new gene editing tool.
  • New moons around old planets: Three new moons were discovered orbiting Uranus and Neptune.
  • Oldest reptile skin: The oldest known fossilized reptile skin was found, dated over 300 million years ago.

2024 was a landmark year for scientific discoveries, setting the stage for future advancements.
newTitle: Yearly round-up: The biggest science stories of 2024

title: Equal to a trillion hydrogen bombs: Is the Sun readying for a violent super explosion? - India Today
summary:
Equal to a trillion hydrogen bombs: Is the Sun readying for a violent super explosion?

Published On: Dec 26, 2024 Source: India Today

An international team of researchers has discovered that sun-like stars, including our own Sun, can produce enormous radiation outbursts known as superflares approximately every hundred years. This is a significant increase compared to prior estimations of their frequency.

  • Superflares release energy levels surpassing a trillion hydrogen bombs.
  • Researchers analyzed data from NASA's Kepler space telescope, identifying 2,889 superflares across 2,527 stars.
  • The occurrence rate of these superflares is substantially higher than previously thought.
  • Evidence from tree rings and glacial ice indicates past extreme solar activities.
  • The study emphasizes the necessity of monitoring sun-like stars for better frequency estimation of superflares.
“The implications for Earth are significant; a superflare could pose even greater risks to modern infrastructure and satellites.” - Dr. Valeriy Vasilyev

Monitoring methods will improve with ESA’s upcoming space probe Vigil, set to enhance monitoring capabilities starting in 2031.
newTitle: Is the Sun Preparing for a Massive Superflare?

title: Asteroid Alert! Airplane-sized Giant Space Rock Set For Close Encounter With Earth On Dec 28, NASA Issues Warn - Times Now
summary:
Asteroid Alert! Airplane-sized Giant Space Rock Set For Close Encounter With Earth On Dec 28

Date: December 28, 2024 | Source: NASA

This week, NASA confirmed that an 80-foot asteroid named 2024 YQ2 will safely pass by Earth on December 28, 2024, at a speed of 58,360 km/h.

  • Asteroid 2024 YQ2 will fly by at a distance of 1,030,000 km, over twice the distance between the Earth and the Moon.
  • Despite its size, 2024 YQ2 is not a threat to Earth and is classified as a Near-Earth Object (NEO).
  • NASA is monitoring near-Earth asteroids to better understand our solar system and refine planetary defense strategies.
  • The NEO Surveyor mission, aimed at improving detection of hazardous asteroids, is set to launch in 2028.
“For an asteroid to be considered a Potentially Hazardous Object, it must be larger than 150 meters and come within 7.5 million kilometers of Earth.”

NASA's ongoing efforts to monitor and study asteroids like 2024 YQ2 underscore the importance of planetary defense and preparedness for potential future threats.
newTitle: Asteroid 2024 YQ2 to Fly By Earth Safely on December 28, 2024

title: Dead Galaxies, Mysterious Red Dots: James Webb Telescope's Findings So Far - NDTV
NASA’s cosmic ‘Wreath’ and ‘Christmas Tree’ shed light on stellar birth and evolution - News9 LIVE
summary:
NASA’s cosmic ‘Wreath’ and ‘Christmas Tree’ shed light on stellar birth and evolution

Date: December 2024

Source: Science News

New Delhi: NASA has revealed breathtaking images of two star clusters, NGC 602 and NGC 2264, resembling festive decorations. These clusters allow astronomers to observe stellar birth in contrasting cosmic environments.

  • The images from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and James Webb Space Telescope show surrounding gas and dust formations.
  • NGC 602, located 200,000 light-years away in the Small Magellanic Cloud, displays young stars in an ionised gas region.
  • NGC 2264 is known as the “Christmas Tree Cluster” and is about 2,500 light-years away, showcasing a conical shape resembling a Christmas tree.
  • The data offers insights into star formation and the life cycle of stars.
“These cosmic images paint how beautiful and intricate the process of star formation is.”

NASA's continuous exploration extends our knowledge of the universe's mysteries, shedding light on the processes of star formation and evolution.
newTitle: NASA's Cosmic Wreath and Christmas Tree Unveiled
